title: 110_s2863
content: The "Ethical Stem Cell Research Tax Credit Act of 2008" is introduced as a credit for ethical stem cell research under the Internal Revenue Code of 1986. The "Ethical Stem Cell Research Tax Credit Act of 2008" allows eligible taxpayers to claim a 30% credit for qualified stem cell research expenses incurred during the taxable year. Eligible taxpayers are those who elect to apply this section for the year. Qualified expenses include those related to basic and applied research for stem cell techniques. The "Ethical Stem Cell Research Tax Credit Act of 2008" allows taxpayers to claim a 30% credit for stem cell research expenses. The act prohibits the creation, destruction, or use of human embryos for research purposes. A human embryo is defined as any organism derived through fertilization, parthenogenesis, cloning, or other means. The "Ethical Stem Cell Research Tax Credit Act of 2008" allows a 30% credit for stem cell research expenses while prohibiting the creation, destruction, or use of human embryos. The act defines a human embryo as any organism derived from human gametes or diploid cells, and it also outlines the risk of injury criteria for human embryos. Qualified stem cell research expenses are not considered for the tax credit under this act. The "Ethical Stem Cell Research Tax Credit Act of 2008" allows a 30% credit for stem cell research expenses while prohibiting the creation, destruction, or use of human embryos. Qualified stem cell research expenses are considered as base period research expenses for subsequent taxable years. No credit is allowed for stem cell research conducted by a corporation with an election under section 936. Aggregation of expenditures and allocations of credit follow rules similar to section 41. The "Ethical Stem Cell Research Tax Credit Act of 2008" amends the Internal Revenue Code to include a credit for ethical stem cell research expenses. This credit is determined under section 45O(a) and denies a double benefit by disallowing a deduction for the same expenses. The credit determined for the taxable year under section 45O(a) may be reduced if the amount exceeds the deduction allowable for qualified stem cell research expenses. Controlled groups rules apply for this subsection. A clerical amendment is made to the Internal Revenue Code. "Part IV of subchapter A of chapter 1 of the Internal Revenue Code of 1986 is amended by adding a new item at the end." "Sec. 45O. Ethical stem cell research. The amendments apply to amounts paid after enactment of this Act."
